description: The purpose of this study plan is to provide a framework for consistent repeated sampling to determine examine trends in the abundance and survival of juvenile summer steelhead out-migrating from Birch Creek.  Out-migrating juvenile steelhead are captured using a rotary screw trap or inclined plan screen trap.  Birch Creek is a major steelhead producing tributary in the Umatilla River and managed as a wild fish sanctuary.  Juvenile steelhead typically exit Birch Creek between December and June, with the majority leaving in early May.  The small stream size and large population size result in ample capture of juveniles resulting in abundance estimates that typically meet recommend data precision standards.
